metadata.sermon_start_end: The famous Dr. Samuel Johnson, author of the first major English dictionary, renowned conversationalist, wit, and man about town, was also a man of deep Biblical faith. When after heroic labors the Great Lexicographer finally finished his Dictionary, he sent the last sheet of manuscript round to the publisher [...] Save us, O LORD our God … that we may give thanks to thy holy name and glory in thy praise. Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting! Let all the people say, ‘Amen!’ Praise the LORD!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s first thesis fundamentally. Instead of recreating one specific Bible passage into a current word, it treats the Bible as a source for a 'biblical keyword' (thanksgiving). It jumps between various Psalms to support a general theme rather than finding what is unique to Psalm 79:13.
quotes: The theme of gratitude is the cantus firmus, the constant undergirding melody of the Biblical song.
Nowhere is the motif of thanksgiving and praise to God more conspicuous than in the Psalms.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope (e.g., Psalm 79) and explore its specific context of national lament. What does it mean to give thanks from a 'pasture' that has been devastated? Avoid using the Bible as a quote-book for a general topic.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of academic exegesis or engagement with the original Hebrew context. The historical situation of the first readers (the destruction of Jerusalem in Psalm 79) is entirely ignored in favor of anecdotes about Samuel Johnson and greeting cards.
quotes: One of the loveliest expressions in all of Scripture is in Psalm 22, verse 3...
Surely this is what the Psalms teach us about our covenant relationship to God.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Apply the requirement of exposition: explain the historical and theological weight of the 'flock' metaphor in the context of Israel's exile or suffering.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its cultural observation (the secularization of Thanksgiving cards), which aligns with Dekker's demand for knowledge of the zeitgeist. However, it often devolves into general psychological advice about 'soul-enlarging' gratitude.
quotes: I went into a shop last week to buy Thanksgiving cards... All references to God had been excised.
Gratitude is soul-enlarging. Gratitude is liberating.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'gratitude as a way of life' toward the concrete 'misery' of the modern hearer that necessitates a specific word of grace from the text.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Because there is no real exposition, there is nothing to interweave. The sermon moves from anecdote to biblical quote to moral application in a linear fashion. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' but rather into a thematic essay.
quotes: The Psalms teach us the purpose and goal of praise.
I have been thinking about this ever since. Her thankfulness created a new situation.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Start with the text's specific tension and let the application emerge directly from the exegetical discovery, rather than using the text to validate personal stories.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon focuses almost exclusively on 'gratitude.' While it mentions 'hard things' and 'adversity,' it treats them as obstacles to be overcome by a 'cheerful disposition' rather than the radical 'misery' of man before God. Redemption is present but remains somewhat objective.
quotes: Wresting humor and ongoing life out of suffering is our best way of being human.
I thank God every day for my cheerful disposition.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. According to Dekker, the sermon should address man's total inability, making the 'redemption' and subsequent 'gratitude' more than just a psychological attitude.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are entirely absent. There is no sense of the possibility of being 'lost'—either temporally or eternally. The tone is universally positive and inclusive, which Dekker warns will lead to traditions disappearing because they take neither man nor God seriously.
quotes: The meaning of life is grounded in the praise of God.
The effects of thanksgiving are freedom and joy.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the gravity of the alternative: what is the 'destruction' that awaits those who refuse to acknowledge the Giver? Address the responsibility of the hearer.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Despite being delivered in 'Trinity Church,' the sermon is barely Christocentric. Christ is not the telos; He is not even mentioned by name in the body of the sermon. It remains a general theistic/Jewish-Christian discourse on 'the Lord.'
quotes: The one that transcends all human contingencies, is thanking and praising God for being God.
We gather together to ask the Lord’s blessing.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make Christ the telos. According to Thesis 7, Christ must be explicitly addressed as the one who is our life, detaching man from himself.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 13.5 minutes, the sermon fails the 20-minute minimum requirement. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth.' It remains at the level of a thematic 'speech' rather than a substantive 'sermon' as defined by Dekker.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical depth and the complexity of the application to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions as a thematic address on the virtue of gratitude rather than a sermon. It lacks a specific biblical anchor, ignores original context, and entirely omits the Christological telos and the 'two ways.' While it shows an adequate understanding of the secular zeitgeist, it remains too general and psychological.
strengths: Adequate cultural analysis of the 'generic' nature of modern secular gratitude.
Clear, traceable structure for a general audience.
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis; treats the Bible as a collection of proof-texts for a topic.
Absence of Christ as the telos of the proclamation.
Insufficient length and depth to be considered a 'sermon' in the Dekkerian sense.
Failure to address the 'two ways' or the radical nature of human misery.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon according to Dekker’s definition; it is a 'speech about a biblical keyword.' It fails the formal requirement of being an exposition of a specific passage and the substantive requirement of being Christocentric and serious about man's destination.
